answers.author: Jared Dailey
answers.text:
Robert:
An excellent resource for the legal steps would be Bob McEvoy, Executive Director, New York State City/County Management Association.  Bob can be reached at 518-442-4396 or rmc@albany.edu.  While I can't speak to the legal requirements, I work on form of government issues here at ICMA and would be more than willing to assist you with other guidance and information.  Please feel free to contact me at 202-962-3557 or jdailey@icma.org.

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
I applaud any government that wants to bring more professionalism to its operation.  I do want to call out one critical point, it is the Council/Manager Plan not the other way around.  This is becuase we recognize that the legilsative body reminas the focus of decision and policy making and the manager is there to serve the city council.  Also, that the executive branch never be represented as more important in the formula then the elected legislative body.  I know the order of the words seems to be a subtitle difference, but it is a critical difference to the profession.  Also, elected's get nervous about the "power" of the chief executive versus their power and putting the manager first can aggravate this existing concern.  Best of Luck.

text: Who can be a resource person that can share the specific legal steps necessary in New York State for a Town to form a Manager-Council form of government from a Supervisor-Council form? Thank you.
title: legal steps to change government structure in New York State
